title: Probe into Volkswagen emissions scandal could take months
text:

Thu, Oct 15, 2015, 14:46 BST - UK Markets close in 1 hr 44 mins Probe into Volkswagen emissions scandal could take months By Alan Tovey | Telegraph – 3 minutes 14 seconds ago 146.50 +1.45 
Volkswagen (Other OTC: VLKAF - news ) 's UK boss says it could be end of the year before investigation reveals who knew what at the stricken car maker 
It (Other OTC: ITGL - news ) could be months before it is known how high up the deceit at Volkswagen (LSE: 0P6N.L - news ) over its emissions cheating went, according to the beleaguered car maker’s UK boss. 
Giving evidence to MPs on the Environmental Audit Committee about the scandal, Paul Willis said it could take until the end of the year before an investigation into who knew about the scandal reports back. 
Mr Willis, who heads VW’s £9bn-a-year UK business, was testifying to MPs about the crisis that has engulfed the German auto maker after it admitted 11m of its diesel-powered cars were fitted with “defeat devices” that allowed then beat pollution tests. 
MPs poured scorn on his and colleagues’ previous claims that the decision to fit the equipment was made by a small group of people and that senior management were unaware of its existence. 
Referring to VW’s top executives, Mr Willis said: “I liaise with certain personalities, I know them really quite well, I find it implausible that this is some sort of deliberate attempt to mislead people. Nobody benefits from rigging tests. 
“I have worked for VW for over 15 years, I understand the structures, the reporting lines, the different pressures and the corporate goals. My opinion is that senior management are very precise, honest and direct people. I don’t think I can say that person is dishonest or that person is honest.” 
MPs also quizzed the executive about suggestions that VW’s 2016 Beetle, Golf, Jetta and Passat (LSE: 0NF6.L - news ) models contain suspect software intended to reduce emissions that is different from the previously admitted defeat devices. Committee chairman Huw Irranca-Davies asked if this signalled the “problem goes deeper than the odd rogue software programmer” and whether there were more admissions to come from VW. 
Mr Willis hit back, saying “it is absolutely not the case that it goes wider” and revealing that the latest devices were part of the process to get cars certified for sale in the US. 
The newly revealed software heats up cars' catalytic convertors to make them more efficient. Regulators have yet to rule if it is designed specifically to beat tests but all such devices have to be revealed to authorities if cars are to receive the certification required for them to go on sale in the US. 
Mr Willis added that VW has 45,000 staff working in technical development and that to try to say exactly who knew what would be “getting dragged into speculation”. 
Mr Willis added that an external investigation by law firm Jones Day should report by the end of the year and the company would share the findings when it gets them. 
“VW’s future depends on transparency,” he said. 
Claims that the scandal will reduce the value of affected cars may be wrong, according to the VW executive. 
“In the US in other cases safety-related issues that killed people and not mentioning names once the fix was made, there was no effect on residual values,” Mr Willis said. 
He added that it was “premature” to talk about compensation but when pushed by the chairman whether “VW would make good if customers have lost out”, Mr Willis replied: “We will sit down with owners if it gets to that point.” 
= Communication = 
Communications between the company and the 1.2m UK motorists affected by the scandal also came under MPs’ scrutiny. The VW boss agreed this could have been better, after MP John McNally referred to “letters woefully short on detail with no mention of redress”. 
“I agree the level of information to customers needs to be faster and to improve,” he said. “Once I knew which cars were affected I started the process of how we would communicate. Now (NYSE: DNOW - news ) the most important thing I can do is… overcommunicate. Our responsibility is to make sure people know.” 
Both Mr Willis and Mike Hawes, chief executive of industry body the Society of Motor Manufacturers and Traders, came under fire over emissions tests on vehicles. 
MPs said the industry was happy to adhere to tests that auto-makers knew were unrealistic, but both men said car companies were meeting the required standards and investing billions in green technology. 
However, Mr Willis said that it was “no secret” there was a gap between emissions in real-world driving and lab tests, and that he would be happy to face tougher standards. 
The news came as German transport regulator KBA ordered a mandatory recall of 2.4m Volkswagen diesel vehicles, having rejected the idea of a "voluntary repair" proposed by the company.
